Award.AwardTitle: Reforming Laboratory Instruction and Hands-on Experiences for the Millennial Learners in STEM

Directorate.LongName: Direct For Education and Human Resources

Award.AbstractNarration: Many educators acknowledge that the millennial generation of students learns like no other, yet little has been done to alter laboratory instruction in response to this generational shift. This project will conduct educational research that evaluates the use of the Case Study Teaching in the Sciences method to improve laboratory instruction. This educational pedagogy promotes the use of cases, or interactive stories, to engage students in STEM courses and to help reform STEM instruction. The cases will be used to introduce the lab concepts as a way to bring relevance to the analytical skills being learned in the lab. The overarching goal for this project is to reform laboratory "step-by-step" instruction to a method that will be more active, engaging and relevant to millennial learners. More specifically, the project will evaluate student learning preferences, student engagement, retention of material, and learning of course concepts using the case studies method. Qualitative and quantitative assessment will be conducted to evaluate student perceptions for use of the methods, student learning gains, and critical thinking of students in biology, environmental engineering, and introductory engineering courses. This study will evaluate and compare data based on gender, ethnicity, and institutional type across three very different university environments. This work has the potential for broad impact because there is widespread interest in improving educational practices across STEM fields. The goal for this work will be to determine if the case studies for laboratory instruction can potentially provide a crosscutting new paradigm for lab instruction.

POR.DRECONTENT:
This educational research focused on the development of novel modules using the Case Studies in the Science Teaching method in introductory seminars and upper level science and engineering laboratory courses. This work was a collaboration between three universities to study the differences in learning preferences for the use of case studies at each institution.  Data was collected at a public, land-grant minority serving institution, a private minority serving liberal arts college for women, and a private, predominantly white liberal arts institution. The goal of the project was to conduct educational research that evaluated the use of the case studies method in science and engineering to improve laboratory and seminar instruction by adding relevant case stories related to the course topic. The full study included quantitative and qualitative assessments in the form of surveys, focus groups with students, and evaluation of student work (lab reports or oral presentations) for quality and content by two external reviewers. Student learning styles (active/reflective, sensing/intuitive, visual/verbal and sequential/global) were also assessed using the Index of Learning Styles Survey (ILSS) by Felder and Solomon. The research investigated student learning preferences, student engagement, retention of material, and learning of course concepts using the case studies method based on ethnicity and institutional type across three environments. The outcomes of this work yielded three American Society for Engineering Education (ASEE) papers, one of which earned a Best Paper Award, two published cases at the National Center for Case Studies Teaching in the Sciences Database, and one journal article published in the Journal of STEM Education. Poster presentations were also delivered at the following conferences:  North Carolina Bridging the GAP Conference, American Society of Cell Biology Conference, and Annual Conference on Case Study Teaching. Our work was featured as part of the 2016 ASEE Sustainability Pre-Conference Workshop. Twenty-three educators, including K-12, community college, and college faculty participated in the Engaging Students with Case Studies Teaching Workshop. This workshop was led by Dr. Clyde “Kipp” Herreid who is the Founder of the National Center for Case Studies Teaching in Science (NCCSTS).

This NSF IUSE research impacted over 370 undergraduate students over the life of the grant. The final study results confirm linkages between student learning preferences and learning gains exist and are statistically significant. Trends within the data support there are differences among the three institutions. The results show that students felt the cases were engaging but the relevance in using the case method versus traditional method was dependent upon: 1) the class subject being taught (i.e., engineering, physics, math, biology), 2) relevance of the case to the topic, and 3) time needed to implement the case versus the key objective. Our hypothesis that the liberal arts students and female students would excel more in critical thinking skills and be more receptive to the case teaching method is currently not supported by the data. We determined the underrepresented groups were more engaged and indicated a strong preference for the case study method because they could see the link to real-world applications.
